title: Wednesday, 29th June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE

Off we go then. Welcome to ML.

BE

And good news! It's an up day.

BE

FTSE back to nearly flat since Friday's open.

11:05 am
BE

Ahead 2.6% at pixel, 6296ish.

BE

And what's that in dollars, you ask? Well, good question. Here's the YTD chart.

BE

11:05 am
BE

So. Still down 10% in dollar terms.

BE

But what about the 250? Well, sure. Down a mere 9% now, the GBK.

BE

Or a slightly less mere 18% in dollar terms.

11:06 am
BE

BE

A reminder that a majority of UK investors don't work in sterling.

BE

ONS estimates 54% of the UK market is owned by foreign investors.

11:07 am
BE

Which is why the recent dead-cat requires a little context added.

undefined
BE

You'll notice that I'm flying solo today. Paul's off at a management meeting.

11:09 am
BE

Which I assume will be trebles all round. ( http://digiday.com...nt-brexit-weekend/ )

BE

I also lost a contact lens shortly before kicking off, so give me a little more leeway than usual.

BE

In terms of where to begin, we have a disconnect ............

11:10 am
BE

Regular media's full of (lightly sourced) stuff saying companies are preparing to up sticks. Vodafone, Visa, etc.

BE

Deepening the general sense of chaos and unpredictability.

BE

Meanwhile, the sellside is saying "hang on though, I can't find the chaos and unpredictability macro on Excel. Things must be cheap."

11:12 am
BE

(@Roddy: that's the most depressing thing I've read this morning. Which in the current context, is quite something.)

BE

We've a wave of upgrades bumping through, which we can address by demand. Housebuilders mentioned on the right so that's as good a starting point as any.

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 1,423, up 79 (+5.88%), High: 1,432, Low: 1,348, Volume: 1.51m
11:13 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 128.60, up 6.6 (+5.41%), High: 129.32, Low: 122.50, Volume: 18.06m
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 399.60, up 18.6 (+4.88%), High: 400.70, Low: 378.00, Volume: 4.24m
BE

Liberum -- who along with Shore have been the most bearish on the housebuilders, upgrade a few. Cautiously.

11:15 am
BE

Largely on the theme we've been banging on about this week, namely (absolute payout) divis should be safe because the sector's fairly easy to run for cash.

BE

Charlie Campbell's the analyst.

BE

Past episodes of slowing GDP growth suggest UK house prices could fall by 3% in 2017. Using this as our central case drives EPS cuts of around 18%, and target price cuts of around 20%. Valuations across the sector are much more compelling after a 34% fall in the shares, especially with dividends mainly intact. We limit our enthusiasm to three high conviction stocks: Bellway (BUY), Berkeley (up from HOLD to BUY) and Gleeson (BUY).

11:17 am
BE

BE

(@doeswalk: that they've fallen pretty close to book value.)

BE

18% EPS downgrades

We have reset our estimates, price targets and recommendations. We have modelled a central case of a 3% fall in UK house prices in 2017 to reflect the slowing GDP that is now widely expected. We see parallels with 1995 and 2012 when house prices declined by around 5% in real terms on GDP slowdowns. Our central case leads to estimate cuts of 18% on average, but dividends are largely unscathed, due to strong balance sheets and landbanks. We do not foresee asset write downs.

11:18 am
BE

Risks balanced from here

The biggest risk is that uncertainty continues for a long time: buyers have delayed purchases in recent years for lesser reasons than current events. Rates and rate expectations appear benign but this could change, and we will need to monitor mortgage availability. Housing affordability is also a challenge, but this will be supported by housing shortages. Build cost inflation is likely to moderate and the land market will only get more benign.

BE

UBS also, which I think was distributed yesterday.

BE

UK housebuilders have declined on average by c25% in response to the UK referendum
to leave the EU. While the impact of this decision is highly uncertain on the
performance of the UK property market, we analyse two scenarios: (1) Downside
18% lower volume vs our base case and 600bps lower EBIT margin by 2019E (i.e. 6%
deflation in real terms) and (2) Bear case 25% lower volumes versus our base case and
1000bps lower EBIT margins (i.e. prices down 10% in real terms). In scenario (1) EPS
forecasts would be cut by 43% vs our base case by 2019E and in scenario (2) by 62%.
We intend to revisit our base cases in due course but provide a simplified analysis of
downside flexes in this note.

11:19 am
BE

Implied ROCE in various scenarios
If our base case (which is likely too optimistic at this stage) is correct, implied LT ROCE
(land creditor adjusted) now stands at 12%, vs 2015 at 21% and long-term average
(2000-2015) of 16%. If we assume scenario (1), market implied LT ROIC would be 16%
and in scenario (2) 21%. Arguably this suggests the market is currently pricing in
around 10% deflation, although if long-term returns are assumed more in line with the
long-term average, there could be an additional 15% downside to share prices.

BE

Long-term fundamentals still good but there are confidence and lending risks
While long-term fundamentals in the sector remain positive (undersupply, Help to Buy
support), the key risk is significantly lower consumer confidence and potentially
increased risk aversion at banks, leading to tighter lending standards. This could result
in house price deflation which is very damaging for housebuilders earnings, given the
sunk cost nature of land. We would note though the sector is well positioned to
weather this storm given most companies are in a net cash position (5% net
cash/equity and even including land credits gearing is only 18%) so any kind of
financial distress is very unlikely, in our view. Post today's fall, the stocks still trade on
1.4x P/TNAV. Dividends could provide some support but could be at risk if prices start
to deflate significantly. While we think value is emerging we believe there is more
potential downside risk to valuations before they become "too good to ignore".

BE

11:21 am
BE

(@roddy1234: CAV is the City's VIP lounge.)

undefined
BE

From the housebuilders to the challenger banks, two sectors that are inextricably linked.

11:22 am
BE

Both reliant on demand for and supply of high LTV loans to buy newbuilds off plan

BE

Quite a dramatic rally in Shawbrook.

Shawbrook Group PLC (SHAW:LSE): Last: 169.58, up 29.58 (+21.13%), High: 180.80, Low: 140.00, Volume: 1.47m
11:24 am
BE

In spite of having no finance director and a few issues adding up its loan book correctly.

BE

Ian Gordon of Investec thinks you over-reacted.

BE

Many investors seemingly regard Shawbrook as a company in crisis yet the key (underlying) drivers appear to tell a very different story. The share price has already halved this month, and received wisdom was that Q2 2016 would see softness after a stellar Q1. The reality is that organic originations are up 35% year-on-year to c.£500m – a new all-time record – helping to deliver sharply improving operational leverage. A raft of executives bought shares in yesterday’s “distressed” market. We believe that this is the bottom. BUY.

11:26 am
BE

(@Soundbuy: the flipside of that is, imagine being a petrodollar-economy type who bought off plan a few months ago. Your desire to complete the deal would depend quite a lot on how much you put down as a deposit.)

BE

Most participants in the buy-to-let market enjoyed strong volumes in Q1 2016, in large part driven by the Chancellor’s stamp duty reform. However, contrary to broader market trends, Shawbrook has maintained good levels of new business origination through Q2 2016 too. Across all business lines, originations have risen to c.£500m in Q2 2016 (Q1 2016: £475m, Q2 2015: £372m). We believe this is usefully ahead of consensus expectations and the underlying business is, we believe, in very good health. Shawbrook targets £5.1bn (150%) loan growth from £3.4bn in 2015 to £8.5bn by 2020.

BE

Yesterday’s unscheduled trading update also disclosed the unwelcome news of a “one-off” £9m impairment charge against £14.7m of impacted facilities relating to irregularities in the Scottish office of the Asset Finance business.

Highly respected CFO Tom Wood has also resigned to spend more time with his family. We see Tom’s departure as a material loss. However, we do see Interim CFO Dylan Minto as an ideal replacement, and we were particularly pleased to see Dylan and colleagues take advantage of yesterday’s distressed share price, collectively buying 126,150 additional shares at £1.39-£1.53 each.

Our existing forecasts were marginally below consensus, and we do recognise an increasing threat from Government policy uncertainty to NIM, loan growth and impairments. We cut our EPS forecasts by 15-19% through 2016-18e.

Perhaps understandably, Shawbrook missed out on yesterday’s market rally, but it now trades on a remarkable 3.9x 2018e EPS. We expect the shares to rally hard from here. Buy rec reaffirmed. TP cut to 295p (from 365p).

11:27 am
BE

3.9 times 2018!

BE

Well, not any more I guess. But still.

BE

Otherwise, sector that falls the most rallies the most.

11:28 am
OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 197.08, up 17.28 (+9.61%), High: 197.40, Low: 185.00, Volume: 296.63k
Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 234.70, up 11.7 (+5.25%), High: 241.40, Low: 228.40, Volume: 880.98k
BE

Oh, with the exception of Paragon.

11:29 am
BE

(@Mouselet: well put.)

BE

Caz downgrades the BTL specialist.

BE

Preamble, which should now be familiar reading ........

11:30 am
BE

Last week, the UK voted to leave the EU, an outcome which has created
heightened uncertainty across markets and the real economy, in our view. In
this note we incorporate some of the potential macro and industry
consequences stemming from a ‘Leave’ vote into our estimates for the
Diversified Financials space, namely a negative MTM impact for AMs
combined with a more muted outlook for flows, and weaker loan book growth
and potentially higher impairments for Specialist Lenders. We accordingly
downgrade earnings for the UK AMs and UK Challenger banks, and also
downgrade recommendations on Aldermore (OW to N), Amundi (OW to N),
Henderson (OW to N) and Paragon (N to UW). In the AM space, our
preferred pick is Partners Group, Provident Financial in the specialist lenders
and Euronext in the exchanges.

BE

And into the detail .......

BE

Share price declines drive a modest de-rating after earning revisions.
We estimate a modest de-rating across the sector on average based on our
revised FY17 earnings. However, we do not believe the de-rating is
sufficient to be positive on the sector given the uncertainties that still exist.
Consequently, we have a preference for stocks that offer greater visibility
through either longer duration assets/surplus capital across asset managers
and lending businesses that have a proven track record through the cycle.

11:31 am
BE

AMs likely to suffer negative MTM impact and subdued net inflows.
After MTM post the Brexit vote and dampening our near-term net flow
outlook (avg. sector net flows/AuM for FY17E are lowered by 5 percentage
points), our FY16E/17E EPS estimates are reduced across the board by
5%/13% on average. We reduce EMG (N) FY16/FY17E earnings by as
much as 23%/29% respectively given the headwind from performance fees.
We retain preference for private market AMs, particularly PGHN (OW,
AFL) which should be more immune to market volatility given the long-
term duration of funds, in our view.

BE

Specialist lenders at risk of deteriorating macro backdrop. A
combination of slower loan book growth, possible uptick in impairments and
potential pressure on net interest margin leads us to cut our FY16/17 EPS
estimates for PAG (UW) and ALD (N) by 7%/29% and 8%/19%,
respectively, and downgrade our recommendations by one notch. While
PFG (OW) could come under pressure, their specialized diverse product
offering and unique customer characteristics renders the business less
susceptible to a potential macro downturn, in our view, and offers a
compelling dividend yield of 5%.

BE

Market Infrastructure well poised to benefit from spurred volatility.
Heightened market volatility could prove beneficial for trading volumes,
which could bode well for ENX (OW). We note however that this could
potentially be offset by lower revenues in listing as investor appetite is more
muted in the near term.

11:32 am
BE

Sorry, no quote box on the last one. Have a chart to compensate.

BE

BE

Prices don't bake in today's rebound.

11:32 am
undefined
BE

(@Golly: agreed, very entertaining. And I had to wind the scorn back by two or three notches in editing.)

BE

And welcome to day .... six? .... of the decline and fall of the United Kingdom.

11:35 am
BE

There's ITV, I guess ........

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 174.10, up 8.1 (+4.88%), High: 174.80, Low: 168.10, Volume: 15.14m
BE

So Deadline Hollywood read Liberum, then the rumourtrage cesspool read Deadline Hollywood, then myself and Alex at the Times read the rumourtrage cesspool, and then Neil Campling read myself and Alex at the Times. That's an outline of how the current bid chatter seems to be travelling.

11:37 am
BE

Still, Neil closes his (extremely profitable) ITV short.

BE

[G]iven the collapse in sterling it is little surprise to see UK targets coming to the fore once again, particularly when the largest ITV shareholder is American (Malone's Liberty Global). Having said that another expected Malone deal, a potential Lions Gate and Starz merger which has been said to be in the works for some time is said to be on the verge of collapse. The NYPost report suggests "Brexit issues kill Lions Gate-Starz merger" with a bank that was going to finance the deal forced to pull out.

BE

In the fallout of Brexit, a number of brokers have cut estimates for ITV 2016 earnings in the range of ~10%. Even after the 7.8% price rise yesterday the stock is off 24% from pre-brexit levels. ITV is now trading at sub 10x P/E and 7.5x 2016 EV/EBITDA. As the chart below shows, ITV has quickly gone from a significant above trend valuation to one of a substantial discount to trend:

11:38 am
BE

BE

Such is the velocity of the move ITV has also moved to a valuation discount to the sector with the SXMP trading at 16x P/E and 10.1x EV/EBITDA. And with a very attractive income stream now offering a 5.2% DY which could well attract a new class of investor and provide support - reminiscent perhaps of the support Pearson has in the wake of structural difficulties. In fact, year to date ITV is now -40% and Pearson +23%, versus the FTSE All-Share Media Index -7.9%.

Adding all of these data points together suggest risk/reward is now more balanced for ITV and the cyclical nature of the advertising cycle well known and reflected in the stock price. As such we recommend CLOSING THE SHORT IN ITV.

BE

But you'll have read that already, I hope. Because what kind of serious investor wouldn't already be on Northern Trust's list? A useless one, is what.

11:40 am
BE

FWIW, we heard some talk around ITV in the month up to the referendum, but nothing felt firm or even close to imminent.

undefined
BE

ROTR, here's your various subscription tiers for the FT.

11:42 am
BE

BE

Newspaper and premium digital, clearly, the best option. You get to see my bowler hat every day.

BE

11:44 am
undefined
BE

Oh, and while on a commercial break ........

BE

CAMP ALPHAVILLE. IT'S ON FRIDAY.

11:45 am
BE

As in, two days away.

BE

And I haven't checked ticket sales this morning, so they're probably sold out.

BE

Making this interlude pointless.

11:46 am
BE

Try your luck here: http://ftalphavill...s-london-hac-july/ ...... Otherwise, you're left to try the scalpers or jump the fence.

BE

(Second option really not recommended. It's an actual army base. There are people with sub machine guns knocking around.)

undefined
11:49 am
BE

I'll get back to corporate in a moment, but I think I saw a few requests for something on the bloc clusterflux.

BE

Jim Reed of Deutsche is always worth sharing, so I will.

BE

When will Article 50 be triggered? Will it ever be triggered? Will there ever
actually be a Brexit? Who is the next Conservative leader? Will there be a snap
general election? Will Jeremy Corbyn cling on to the leadership of the Labour
Party in spite of a stunning 172/212 MPs in his party supporting a no
confidence vote in him? Will the UK have a 2nd referendum? On any
negotiations will Europe play hard ball or compromise? Will the UK let down
swathes of the 'leave' voters and strike a compromise deal (eg like Norway)
that doesn't address the immigration issue at the heart of many voters’ fears?
Elsewhere will Italy lose the senate reform referendum in October and could
Italy have an EU referendum after a fresh election? And will the French
elections next year be another spoke in the wheel for Europe?

11:51 am
BE

These questions and many more will remain mostly unanswered for many
months which is sure to keep risk premiums on the higher side. However
yesterday was a day for thinking the glass as being 10% full rather than 90%
empty as various theories were distributed about whether Brexit would
actually ever happen or whether some market friendly outcome would
eventually be seen. There's a possibility of such outcomes but we won't know
that for many many months and possibly much longer so expect lots of mood
swings ahead as the prevailing mood changes but there was definitely an air
that full Brexit wasn't necessarily a done deal yesterday.

BE

My favourite comment across the day though was from the Luxembourg PM
Xavier Bettel who said "Married or divorced, but not something in between.
We are not on Facebook with 'it’s complicated' as a status". Those were the
days!!

BE

(@PeterC: only banks covering it so far also ran the float. We'll update as soon as that changes. There's plenty of string in the AV archive though.)

11:52 am
BE

That came alongside a flurry of other chatter from various EU leaders, all of
which appeared to turn up the pressure valve on Cameron and the UK. Late in
the evening we heard German Chancellor Merkel come out and say that ‘as of
this evening, I see no way back from the Brexit vote’ and that ‘this is no time
for wishful thinking, but to rather grasp reality’. Leaders from Belgium,
Sweden and Denmark all voiced their frustrations and urged the UK to move
quickly towards exit so as to reduce the uncertainty. Meanwhile French
President Francois Hollande also added that the ‘UK won’t be able to access
the single market without applying the rules of freedom of movement’.
Interestingly, yesterday French press Le Figaro released an opinion poll which
showed 45% of French citizens would be in favour of remaining in the EU,
versus 33% against. Given all of the events of the last week, polls like this will
only take on more and more focus.

BE

Elsewhere ECB President Draghi also weighed in suggesting that the Brexit
vote could result in euro area GDP being cut by as much as 0.5% over the next
three years, although unsurprisingly he did cite that the Bank would do
everything necessary to ensure price stability. The EU Leader’s summit
continues for a second day today so expect the headlines to be dominated by
that once again.

BE

Head over to the Brexit blog for more of that.

11:54 am
BE

Meanwhile, Malcolm Barr of JP Morgan has some valid follow-on points to Gideon Rachman's "it won't happen" column the other day.

BE

This one: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4CxYvLHOL

BE

He's not terribly confident.

11:55 am
BE

Those who argue that a UK exit from the EU will ultimately not happen appear to be making two key arguments (see, for example, Gideon Rachman at the link below). First, Boris Johnson (favourite to become new PM) floated the idea of a second renegotiation of EU membership terms after an exit vote prior to the referendum. Having become PM, that may be the path he goes down. Second, if the EU were prepared to offer some form of control on migration flows for the UK (for example, an emergency brake on numbers of inflows) there would be grounds for a compromise deal which keeps the UK in the EU. And some in the region (Germany is the most often cited) may be prepared to offer that compromise. Our base case is that EU exit will occur, so we address both of these arguments in turn.

BE

On Boris….(and others)
Mr Johnson’s suggestion that a "leave" vote could be followed by further negotiations was fiercely rejected by other EU members. Indeed, David Cameron’s new terms for EU membership were explicitly tied to the referendum result, and those terms have now been withdrawn. During the referendum campaign itself, Johnson made no further mention of the possibility of renegotiation. Instead the focus was to “take back control” across migration and a number of other areas, including trade deals, regulatory policy and so on. One can argue that this was simply positioning for the purposes of the referendum and that, with the passage of time, cooler heads will prevail. However, this would be to under-appreciate the influence of two forces: the power of the referendum result itself, and the strength of feeling among those who have long campaigned for the UK to exit from the EU.

The latter group are located primarily within the membership of the Conservative party, and have adopted the charismatic Mr Johnson as their champion. Referenda are rare events in the UK, and are treated by politicians and the civil service as generating “instruction” to politicians as they crystallise “the manifest will of the British people”. Few politicians have the ability to reinvent themselves that Mr Johnson has. But our view is that his ability to move away from an “implementing Brexit” position will be very constrained by domestic political forces. Potential economic weakness is an influence on attitudes, but one should not underestimate the ability of a Brexit government to endure the “transitional cost” of leaving the EU. In our view, it will take sustained contraction in output and sharp increases in unemployment for that pressure to materially affect this process.

BE

The four fundamental freedoms
The four fundamental freedoms of the EU are freedom of movement of goods, services, people, and capital. One can argue about the extent to which these have all been delivered in practise (particularly on services). But there is little doubt that this integrative idea is foundational to how the EU has evolved. Free movement of people has seen an enormous challenge through the migration crisis in the region, with concerns about migration policy extending beyond the UK. However, the response including the deal with Turkey appears to be preventing an intensification of these pressures for now. The commitment to free movement of people in the EU has not been absolute, however. For example, transitional limits on migration flows were allowed for a number of years in the region in the wake of the accession of 8 countries in eastern Europe to the EU in 2004. So the key question at this point is whether the EU is prepared to offer a more fundamental compromise on free movement to the UK. Our best guess is that the answer is no.

Politicians within the EU are aware of the fragility of the structure at this point. There is recognition of a need for the region to evolve, amid differing ideas as to how that should happen. Having gone through a negotiation process with the UK, the rest of the region is aware of the precedent that would be set by agreeing to the UK’s wishes as a result of the threat of withdrawal. So the key question is whether the costs of Brexit for the EU exceed the benefits of reasserting the primacy of free movement and of the region's established negotiating processes. At least some in the leave camp in the UK have made the judgement that the EU will bend in the UK’s direction. If we were at a less fragile moment in the regions evolution, we might agree with them. But in the same way that the region was not prepared to allow Greece to step out of the rules of the game, we expect the same will apply to the UK. Some politicians in the region are sympathetic to some of the UK’s concerns. But we do not believe the core countries will make an exception for the UK.

11:56 am
undefined
BE

Not long left and I feel we've only covered a fraction of what needs mentioned.

BE

There's a Merrill upgrade of Burberry, pointing out that it's quite dollar sensitive.

11:58 am
Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,147, up 47 (+4.27%), High: 1,151, Low: 1,124, Volume: 1.22m
BE

And a Sophos trading update, pointing out that numbers haven't collapsed yet.

BE

Which is lovely, but one can question how important that guidance is

11:59 am
BE

Given we're at the end of the second quarter

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 190.70, up 8.7 (+4.78%), High: 198.40, Low: 190.00, Volume: 696.03k
BE

And as every salesperson will tell you, there's a huge rush at the end of each quarter to make targets, the second being the most important for subscription software companies.

12:00 pm
BE

Haitong noted this today with reference to SAP.

BE

Can you imagine trying to close large software sales in Europe this week, the final and most important week of the quarter? Anyone who is trying to get any decisions made in the UK or Europe at this time knows that’s a tough job. SAP estimates that a minimum of 20% of software license sales are ‘back end loaded’. That is industry speak for ‘last minute’ when the best deals are to be had. We believe the number may be closer to 40%, or even higher this quarter due to macro uncertainties in Europe (BREXIT, European equity market weakness, European banks’ instability). We believe that more than a quarter of those deals could slip (as they did in Q1) resulting in a 12% miss of consensus software license expectations, and causing SAP to abandon its guidance for ‘flattish’ software revenue growth for FY 2016. For the FY, we are now 12% below consensus EPS estimates. Maintain SELL and FV of €45 / $50.

BE

.... which looks a sensible argument, to me.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE

Elsewhere in the inbox, Martin Hughes reckons everything's awesome.

BE

TOSCAFUND MAKES POSITIVE UK FORECAST POST-BREXIT

12:03 pm
BE

You'll remember Toscafund's main fund lost four-fifths of its value in 2009.

BE

29 June 2016, London, United Kingdom- Toscafund Asset Management LLP today publishes a discussion paper providing further economic analysis on the UK’s future, after the results of last week’s referendum. Authored by Chief Economist Dr. Savvas Savouri, these insights follow his initial contention that it would be better, economically, to exit the European Union.
Toscafund has a proven track record of counter-consensual forecasting including: a positive view of London in 2009 after the global financial crisis, “Britain’s Got Growth:” a positive view of the UK in 2012 when others were predicting double-dip recession and a positive view of regional UK growth in late 2013.

BE

There's being contrarian, and there's being contrarian for the sake of it .....

12:04 pm
BE

Still, here are the bullet points.

BE

One of the most remarkable experiences of recent days is having discussions with ‘market participants’ who were not working in capital markets in 1992 and many had not even been born then. I do not pick this year randomly but because it was the year the UK made its EXIT from the ERM. In the wake of this the pound fell, GDP recovered strongly (see Chart 2 and 4) and the FTSE ultimately surged. Well, it should really be dÃ©jÃ vu all over again. And the reason it hasn’t been thus far being precisely because so many participants in capital markets were not participating then. Well, I can say that most of the Partners at Toscafund were very much working in finance in 1992 and we know what comes next.
Yes, the pound has weakened. But no, it has not done so by a percentage which has not been experienced before; experienced before and, I hasten to add, enjoyed the competitiveness-enhancing consequences of before (see Chart 1). Yes, the UK equity market recently moved lower, but not by a percentage outside of our experiences. And whilst equity prices edged downwards, Gilt prices went higher, for me a reassuring and more than justified move given the UK economy’s sound fundamentals.
Back in the wake of our EXIT from the ERM interest rates were cut as the currency fell. The former lifted what had been appallingly weak domestic demand whilst the latter lifted trade.
This time around the domestic economy is actually in far stronger shape and the employment level today stands at 34.3 million compared to 27.6 million in 1992 (see Chart 3). Moreover, the domestic economy is far more service orientated today than in 1992; the index of services currently stands at 110. It had not been created back in 1992, beginning in 1997 at 65. Since then it has compounded at an annual real growth rate of 2.7%. Services will continue to be a long-term driver for UK economic growth.
Back in 1992, there was no China on the global stage. Now it is a growth behemoth whose strength many across the emerging world feed off. And few nations in the developed world have greater connectivity with it than we do across the UK. Back in 1992 Central and Eastern Europe were still outside the EU and struggling to see clearly in post-communist daylight. This time, the likes of Poland et al would prove our loudest EU supporters to avoid the UK being rusticated from it.
That was before the Single Labour Market. Now watch as EU nationals from France, Italy et al flock here, fearing that if they delay they might be “gated out”. Watch too as our Universities are overwhelmed by applicants from beyond the EU looking to capitalise on the cuts to our tuition fees brought about by sterling weakness. Also, listen out for the container ships filled with UK made cars heading for customers across mainland Europe and beyond it taking advantage of our improved competitiveness. Watch and listen as our economy strengths rather than struggles as so many youthful and inexperienced commentators claim. Keep an eye out too for inflation which did not surge post our EXIT from the ERM and neither will it surge now. In our reasoned and seasoned expectation, consumer price inflation will settle nicely within the range 1-3% which the Bank of England is mandated to achieve.
Toscafund’s forecast for UK GDP growth in 2017 is a range of 1.8%-2.2%. More importantly, the medium-term outlook ultimately benefits from the exit.

undefined
12:05 pm
BE

Cripes. Look at the time.

BE

Pru's a Barclays upgrade.

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,259, up 68.5 (+5.75%), High: 1,274, Low: 1,217, Volume: 3.56m
12:06 pm
BE

Electrocomponents is a Credit Suisse downgrade.

Electrocomponents PLC (ECM:LSE): Last: 251.80, down 9.4 (-3.60%), High: 255.60, Low: 243.30, Volume: 568.94k
